instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] Knocked over case pin, ruined board?
threads.message:
Currently working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which doesn't boot at all (No fan spin, green light then turns orange) and I've noticed that one of those pins that ground the casing have been knocked over. This exposes some of the traces in the board but I don't think there are any broken connections.

Picture:[URL]https://i.imgur.com/GFpcouU.jpg[/URL] & [URL]https://i.imgur.com/LJFhL3S.jpg[/URL]

The few metal things that are stuck on the pin all seem to be connected to the pin itself, which if it was still on the board would probably just connect the pin to those pads/holes?

I think it should be alright, but I just wanted to make sure this is not the reason why the board would be non-functional. I rather don't want to spent hours of time just to realise its fucked :p

Thanks!

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] Knocked over case pin, ruined board?
threads.message: Nah, just rip it off. Look for liquid, PPBUS, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] Knocked over case pin, ruined board?
threads.message:
I ripped it off cleanly

Anyways some more serious stuff, this doesn't look too well...

[URL]https://i.imgur.com/5cOlKsk.jpg[/URL]

Any tips on what approach to take to restore these pads?

Also <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7323</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7372</CAPACITOR> seem to be ripped off but their legs are still soldered on. I've never soldered caps like this so I have no idea how to properly desolder them from a donor board and solder them on. Especially when the legs are still in. What approach to take?

(Since these caps are missing, would this be a reason for it not to enter a S0 state?)

Thanks again and sorry for being the biggest noob :o, Glad you're here to help

EDIT: Also the yellow stuff on the pads, is that just glue or are those actual lines? I've never had ripped off pads before on a board and I need to know if I can scrape them away without ruining the complete board.

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] Knocked over case pin, ruined board?
threads.message:
There are no pads to restore, there is nothing damaged you are just looking at fibers of the PCB material.
All those missing caps are not critical for operation. It does make me question as to what happened to this board. Looks like it was thrown around, so more missing parts are to be expected.

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] Knocked over case pin, ruined board?
threads.message:
This board has definitely seen better times, I have no idea what happened to it, other then it being damaged or missing some components I see no other damage to the board and/or his traces though. It has suffered from water damage but sadly I think someone else tried to "fix" it by just putting it in a ultrasonic (Which might have been to aggressive and knocked these parts off?). The water indicators are bright red but I don't see any corrosion at all

I'll continue diagnosing the board soon, when I'm finished I'd love to put at least a few of those capacitors back. I don't think its alright to call it a quality repair while various parts are missing from the board.

How do I go and restore the pads for <CAPACITOR>C7619</CAPACITOR> and replace the 6 other caps just like it? (Some of them only have legs, but a few at a different part of the board have cracks going through them and I don't trust them to last) I tried looking on Louis his channel but I'm unable to find a video where he replaces these capacitors.

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] Knocked over case pin, ruined board?
threads.message:
So far you have not provided any measurements. PPBUS? <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>? etc
<CAPACITOR>C7619</CAPACITOR> is not needed for the board to work

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] Knocked over case pin, ruined board?
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.47v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> 12.45v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER3V3</SIGNAL> 12.45v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER5V</SIGNAL> 12.45v

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.37v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> 16.47v (Yes, its a 60W charger, the other one is currently in use but since its a 13" model it should be alright)
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 16.43v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5.00v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> 0v
...

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 0v
...

The board is also missing quite a few parts, most of them are ripped off but some are actually desoldered:

Missing: <CAPACITOR>C0890</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C0891</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C0892</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C1264</CAPACITOR>, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C6919</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7323</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7372</CAPACITOR>

There has definitely been screwed with this board, I'll try to fix it but honestly I think I should accept I've been scammed for a very expensive donor board

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] Knocked over case pin, ruined board?
[<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] Knocked over case pin, ruined board?
threads.message:
Short on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> (measured at <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR>, pin 1)

Its currently 1AM so I'll continue working on it tomorrow, I'll probably check out the schematics to follow the line and check the parts along the way. Any tips or specific area's to look at?

Thanks!

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] Knocked over case pin, ruined board?
threads.message: Probably shorted CPU then if <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and those caps are already gone.

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] Knocked over case pin, ruined board?
threads.message:
Darn, there indeed isn't anything left on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> to cause a short other then the CPU.

Do you think the CPU is toast or could re-balling may work?

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>] Knocked over case pin, ruined board?
threads.message: Probably toasted, but for practice you can try and reball.
